text: rebuilding the barricades during the
morning lull after a second night of
violence in the very center of Kiev with
the numbers of injured mounting on both
sides there is no sign of an end to this
political crisis
it may seem extraordinary but this is
the hill that leads up to Ukraine's
national parliament and now it's a scene
of utter devastation you can see the
cobblestones on the ground that
protesters have been throwing at police
the remains of gas masks there's bits of
petrol bombs Thrun all over the place it
is quite quiet here at the moment but
nobody knows when the violence is going
to begin again last night protesters
hurled petrol bombs at police for hours
on end
they also used fireworks like rocket
launchers to sow confusion in the police
ranks though their defensive line held
officers then arrested the men who'd
fired on them blatantly beating them in
front of the furious crowd in the middle
of it all President Yanukovych appeared
on national television when peaceful
actions turn into mass unrest riots
awesome and violence they pose a threat
not just to give but to all of Ukraine
in fact the serious violence has been
restricted to a few hundred protesters
in a small square near Parliament but
the president's remarks have only
deepened the sense of crisis what began
as a long-running demonstration in
favour of joining the European Union was
inflamed by new laws restricting the
right to protest and it's now an
anarchic mess with no obvious solution
Daniel Sanford BBC news Kiev
